column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=MAX BEERBOHM
#Text=I was shocked this morning when I saw in my newspaper a paragraph announcing his sudden death .
#Text=I do not say that the shock was very disagreeable .
#Text=One reads a newspaper for the sake of news .

#Text=Had I never met James Pethel , belike I should never have heard of him : and my knowledge of his death , coincident with my knowledge that he had existed , would have meant nothing at all to me .
#Text=If you learn suddenly that one of your friends is dead , you are wholly distressed .

#Text=If the death is that of a mere acquaintance whom you have recently seen , you are disconcerted , pricked is your sense of mortality ; but you do find great solace in telling other people that you met " the poor fellow " only the other day , and that he was " so full of life and spirits , " and that you remember he said -- whatever you may remember of his sayings .
#Text=If the death is that of a mere acquaintance whom you have not seen for years , you are touched so lightly as to find solace enough in even such faded reminiscence as is yours to offer .
#Text=Seven years have passed since the day when last I saw James Pethel , and that day was the morrow of my first meeting with him .
#Text=I had formed the habit of spending August in Dieppe .
#Text=The place was then less overrun by trippers than it is now .
#Text=Some pleasant English people shared it with some pleasant French people .
#Text=We used rather to resent the race-week -- the third week of the month -- as an intrusion on our privacy .
#Text=We sneered as we read in the Paris edition of " The New York Herald " the names of the intruders , though by some of these we were secretly impressed .

column1: #Text=We disliked the nightly crush in the baccarat-room of the casino , and the croupiers ' obvious excitement at the high play .
#Text=I made a point of avoiding that room during that week , for the special reason that the sight of serious , habitual gamblers has always filled me with a depression bordering on disgust .
#Text=Most of the men , by some subtle stress of their ruling passion , have grown so monstrously fat , and most of the women so harrowingly thin .
#Text=The rest of the women seem to be marked out for apoplexy , and the rest of the men to be wasting away .
#Text=One feels that anything thrown at them would be either embedded or shattered , and looks vainly among them for one person furnished with a normal amount of flesh .

#Text=Monsters they are , all of them , to the eye , though I believe that many of them have excellent moral qualities in private life ; but just as in an American town one goes sooner or later -- goes against one 's finer judgment , but somehow goes -- into the dime-museum , so year by year , in Dieppe 's race-week , there would be always one evening when I drifted into the baccarat-room .
#Text=It was on such an evening that I first saw the man whose memory I here celebrate .
#Text=My gaze was held by him for the very reason that he would have passed unnoticed elsewhere .
#Text=He was conspicuous not in virtue of the mere fact that he was taking the bank at the principal table , but because there was nothing at all odd about him .
#Text=He alone , among his fellow-players , looked as if he were not to die before the year was out .
#Text=Of him alone I said to myself that he was destined to die normally at a ripe old age .

#Text=Next day , certainly , I would not have made this prediction , would not have " given " him the seven years that were still in store for him , nor the comparatively normal death that has been his .
#Text=But now , as I stood opposite to him , behind the croupier , I was refreshed by my sense of his wholesome durability .
#Text=Everything about him , except the amount of money he had been winning , seemed moderate .
#Text=Just as he was neither fat nor thin , so had his face neither that extreme pallor nor that extreme redness which belongs to the faces of seasoned gamblers : it was just a clear pink .
#Text=And his eyes had neither the unnatural brightness nor the unnatural dullness of the eyes about him : they were ordinarily clear eyes , of an ordinary gray .
#Text=His very age was moderate : a putative thirty-six , not more .
#Text=( " Not less , " I would have said in those days . )
#Text=He assumed no air of nonchalance .
#Text=He did not deal out the cards as though they bored him , but he had no look of grim concentration .
#Text=I noticed that the removal of his cigar from his mouth made never the least difference to his face , for he kept his lips pursed out as steadily as ever when he was not smoking .
#Text=And this constant pursing of his lips seemed to denote just a pensive interest .
#Text=His bank was nearly done now ; there were only a few cards left .

#Text=Opposite to him was a welter of party-colored counters that the croupier had not yet had time to sort out and add to the rouleaux already made ; there were also a fair accumulation of notes and several little stacks of gold -- in all , not less than five-hundred pounds , certainly .
#Text=Happy banker !
#Text=How easily had he won in a few minutes more than I , with utmost pains , could win in many months !
#Text=I wished I were he .
#Text=His lucre seemed to insult me personally .
#Text=I disliked him , and yet I hoped he would not take another bank .
#Text=I hoped he would have the good sense to pocket his winnings and go home .
#Text=Deliberately to risk the loss of all those riches would intensify the insult to me .
